current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of
		  1965 to support teacher and school professional training on awareness of
		  student mental health conditions.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Helping Educators Support All
			 Students Act

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text:
Approximately 1
			 in 5 children have a diagnosable mental illness.

Fifty percent of
			 all lifetime cases of mental illness begin by age 14, and 75 percent by age
			 24.

Fifty percent of
			 students with a mental illness, age 14 years and older, drop out of high
			 school.

For youth between
			 the ages of 10 and 24, suicide is the third leading cause of death, and an
			 estimated 90 percent have a diagnosable mental health condition.

One in 10
			 children and adolescents suffer from mental illness severe enough to cause some
			 level of impairment, but only 1 in 5 of such children receive specialty mental
			 health services.

header.#text:
Training
			 teachers and school professionals in understanding mental health conditions in
			 children

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subpart 2 of part A
			 of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:IV/pt:A/spt:2
usc/20/7131/etseq

header.#text:
Training
				teachers and school professionals in understanding mental health conditions in
				children

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall award grants to eligible State
				educational agencies to enable such agencies to award subgrants to eligible
				local educational agencies to support an existing, or develop a new, program
				that will educate teachers, school personnel, and specialized instructional
				support personnel on mental health conditions in children, including the
				causes, symptoms, and impact on learning.

text.#text: The

In
				this section:

term.#tail:
means a local educational agency or a local educational agency in
				partnership with a mental health organization, family advocacy organization, or
				community nonprofit organization.

means

text.#text: An application submitted under

to best
				communicate with families about these concerns;

to identify
				classroom strategies for working effectively with children with mental health
				conditions; and

to understand
				school specific information, including, as appropriate, how schools are—

assisting in
				linking students to supports and services; and

providing
				information on the school’s mental health services and supports, including
				school social work and psychological services, as well as the school’s referral
				process for additional school-linked services connecting to community mental
				health professionals.

An eligible local educational agency that receives a
				subgrant under this section shall support an existing training program
				developed by either the school or a community organization with expertise in
				the lived experience of mental illness, or develop a new program, in which
				school counselors, school psychologists, and school social workers develop and
				provide training to teachers, school personnel, and specialized instructional
				support personnel in understanding the mental health needs of children. Such
				program shall include an annual in-service training program to enable such
				teachers, school personnel, and specialized instructional support
				personnel—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall incorporate family and parent perspectives.
